Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: ANALYSIS SOURCE: The source that the analysis came from, this could be a labtechnician, a lab, a company, a government agency, etc.
Column Comment.2: EQUIPMENT OBSERVATION NUMBER: A unique number which allows for multipleobservations by a piece of equipment during sample analysis.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: CALLIBRATION RECORD: These are typically ASCII files provided along with labresults, often as a text tile, or a paper document. The information includes data abouthow the equipment was configured or calibrated for the stufy, and may provide usefulbenchmarks for comparing studies or understanding the results of one study. Youcan capture the contents of a text file in this record, or point to the RM module for thelocation of a paper or digital document (use ANL COMPONENT for the FK)
Column Comment.5: EQUIPMENT CATALOGUE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the list of kinds ofequipment. Think of this as a catalogue or brochure that shows all the kinds ofequipment that you may use, but may or may not actually have. Actual pieces ofequipment thatexist are defined in the table EQUIPMENT.
Column Comment.6: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first comes into effect.
Column Comment.7: EQUIPMENT IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the specific piece of equipment usedin this study. If you only know the general make and model of the equipment, useCAT EQUIP ID.
Column Comment.8: EQUIPMENT ROLE: The role a particular piece of equipment plays in the sampleanalysis.
Column Comment.9: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row is no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.10: LABORATORY BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for abusiness associate within a laboratory.
Column Comment.11: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.12: PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not there is a problem withthe step. If a yes flag is indicated, additional information regarding the problemshould be noted in the table ANL_PROBLEM.
Column Comment.13: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.14: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.15: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample. This column is asufficient method to keep track of what is done in the sample analysis. However, ifthe requirement for more complicated tracking such as two steps occurringsimultaneously or if steps are needed to be added to the initial procedure, use thetwo columns STEP_SEQ_NO1 and STEP_SEQ_NO2 in the tableANL_STEP_XREF.
Column Comment.16: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.17: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.18: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.19: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.20: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.21: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.22: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
